description: a(0)=1, a(1)=1, a(n) = largest prime <= a(n-1)+a(n-2).
comments: Might be called the Prime-Fibonacci sequence. - _Bodo Zinser_, Nov 17 2001Or might be called Ishikawa primes, as he proved that prime(n+2) < prime(n) + prime(n+1) for n > 1. This improves on Bertrand's Postulate (Chebyshev's theorem), which says prime(n+2) < prime(n+1) + prime(n+1). - _Jonathan Sondow_, Sep 21 2013
references: H. Ishikawa, Über die Verteilung der Primzahlen, Sci. Rep. Tokyo Univ, Lit a. Sci. Sect. A, 2 (1934), 27-40.
links: Zak Seidov and Michael De Vlieger, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..1000 (First 100 terms from Zak Seidov)
formula: a(n) is asymptotic to C*phi^n where phi=(1+sqrt(5))/2 and C=0.25861637901860700965101922576495456677... - _Benoit Cloitre_, Apr 21 2003a(n) = A007917(a(n-1) + a(n-2)) for n > 1. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, May 01 2013a(n) >= prime(n-1) for n > 1, by Ishikawa's theorem. - _Jonathan Sondow_, Sep 21 2013
example: a(9) = 23 because 23 is largest prime <= a(7)+a(6) = 17+11 = 28
